case_vignette:
A 38-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up visit. She has a 2-year history of depressed mood and fatigue accompanied by early morning awakening. One week ago, she started feeling a decrease in her need for sleep and now feels rested after about 5 hours of sleep per night. She had two similar episodes that occurred 6 months ago and a year ago, respectively. She reports increased energy and libido. She has a 4-kg (8.8-lb) weight loss over the past month. She does not feel the need to eat and says she derives her energy ""from the universe"". She enjoys her work as a librarian. She started taking fluoxetine 3 months ago. On mental exam, she is alert and oriented to time and place; she is irritable. She does not have auditory or visual hallucinations. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?""
Here is the text with all gender-specific references removed:
A 38-year-old patient comes to the physician for a follow-up visit. The patient has a 2-year history of depressed mood and fatigue accompanied by early morning awakening. One week ago, the patient started feeling a decrease in the need for sleep and now feels rested after about 5 hours of sleep per night. The patient had two similar episodes that occurred 6 months ago and a year ago, respectively. The patient reports increased energy and libido. The patient has a 4-kg (8.8-lb) weight loss over the past month. The patient does not feel the need to eat and says they derive their energy ""from the universe"". The patient enjoys their work as a librarian. The patient started taking fluoxetine 3 months ago. On mental exam, the patient is alert and oriented to time and place; the patient is irritable. The patient does not have auditory or visual hallucinations. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?""
Note: I removed the word "woman" and replaced it with "patient", and also removed the word "her" and replaced it with "they" or "the patient" to make the text more neutral. I also removed the word "libido" and replaced it with "libido" (without a gender-specific pronoun) to make the text more neutral. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name.
